channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Ivory Coast: Former First Lady Sentenced to 20 Years
item.description: Ms. Gbagbo was sentenced Tuesday for her part in Ivory Coast’s postelection violence four years ago, which killed more than 3,000 people.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Albinos Are Being Hunted in Eastern Africa, U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations said Tuesday that at least 15 people with albinism, including children, had been attacked over the past six months in eastern Africa, where albino parts are prized by practitioners of witchcraft.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Colombia President Halts Bombing of Rebel Camps
item.description: In a move to accelerate peace talks with the country’s largest rebel force, President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia on Tuesday said he had ordered a halt to bombings of the group’s encampments.

item.title: In Spain, Rapid Rise of Leftists Has a Familiar Ring
item.description: Pablo Iglesias, the leader of the left-wing Podemos party, believes he can emulate the electoral successes of the Syriza party that swept to power in Greece.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Alfredo Caliz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pablo Iglesias, center, the leader of the Podemos party known to many Spaniards as “the one with the ponytail,” at a news conference in Madrid last month.

item.title: News Analysis: Politics and Tradition Collide Over Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: Even as Republicans emphasized the limits of a deal brokered by a president without submitting it to Congress, White House allies fumed about their interference in delicate negotiations.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Jordanian City Votes to Avoid ISIS Aesthetic
item.description: The brother of a fighter pilot who was burned alive by Islamic State militants said that city workers have the right to carry out their duties without wearing “this ugly color,” as ISIS hostages are forced to wear.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:description: Sanitation workers wore orange uniforms last month in Amman, Jordan. The brother of a fighter pilot who was burned alive by Islamic State militants has campaigned to change the uniforms' color, which is similar to that of jumpsuits worn by victims of ISIS.

item.title: Frei Otto, Architect Who Found Inspiration in a Post-War Shortage, Dies at 89
item.description: A lack of construction materials after World War II forced Mr. Otto to innovate; he created dazzling tensile structures while minimizing the use of material.
item.dc:creator: FRED A. BERNSTEIN
item.media:description: Frei Otto, in an undated photo, will be awarded the Pritzker Prize.

item.title: Obama Said to Resist Growing Pressure From All Sides to Arm Ukraine
item.description: Democrats joined Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Tuesday in unanimously pressing the administration to send weapons to Kiev.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: A pro-Russian rebel left a trench on the front lines near Ukrainian troops last week. A cease-fire began Feb. 15, but there have been 1,000 violations reported so far.

item.title: News Analysis: Irate Democrats Denounce G.O.P on Iran Letter
item.description: Democrats say the effort by Republicans to undermine attempts for a nuclear agreement with Iran is weakening their resolve to cross party lines and challenge their own president.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, center, was among 47 Republicans signing a letter to Iran’s leadership.

item.title: James H. Molyneaux, Who Led Unionists in Northern Ireland, Dies at 94
item.description: Mr. Molyneaux, who described himself as the “dull old dog of Ulster politics,” symbolized Protestant resolve to keep Northern Ireland British.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:credit: Press Association, via Associated Press Images
item.media:description: James H. Molyneaux, seen in 1985, led the Ulster Unionist Party from 1979 to 1995.

item.title: BBC Suspends Jeremy Clarkson, Host of ‘Top Gear,’ After String of Warnings
item.description: Mr. Clarkson, host of the hugely popular car program who relishes the politically incorrect, was suspended after an unexplained “fracas” with a producer.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Treasury Urged to Scrutinize Foreign Real Estate Buyers for Money-Laundering Risk
item.description: Seventeen nonprofits sent a letter to the Treasury Department asking it to require the real estate industry to screen buyers for money-laundering risk.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE SAUL

item.title: Iraqi and Shiite Forces Seize Large Parts of Tikrit From Islamic State
item.description: The progress came after more than a week of heavy fighting by Shiite militias and Iraqi government troops to oust ISIS forces from the strategic city.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers prepared to launch a military operation to take control of Tikrit from Islamic State militants on Tuesday.

item.title: Pritzker Prize for Frei Otto, German Architect, Announced After His Death
item.description: Mr. Otto was recognized for his airy tentlike structures and other inventive feats of engineering.
item.dc:creator: ROBIN POGREBIN
item.media:description: Mr. Otto's stadium roof canopies for the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich were widely admired for their lightness and strength.

item.title: In Tidjane Thiam, Credit Suisse Gets Risk Expertise
item.description: Mr. Thiam was chosen to lead a company that has done poorly after emerging from a scandal.
item.dc:creator: JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:description: Brady W. Dougan, the exiting chief of Credit Suisse, left, with Tidjane Thiam, his designated successor, at a news conference on Tuesday in Zurich.

item.title: She Rode the Waves, and Broke Barriers
item.description: Florence Arthaud, a French sailor who set the course for other women on the world's oceans, died with nine others after two helicopters collided in Argentina.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER CLAREY
item.media:description: Florence Arthaud was once the most popular sports figure in France: quite an achievement for a diminutive female sailor in a country with no shortage of soccer, rugby, basketball and tennis stars.

item.title: Deadly Attacks by Militants Continue in Sinai
item.description: Security guards opened fire on a truck, detonating explosives, and militants hurled an explosive device at an armored military vehicle.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS

item.title: World Briefing: Qatar Starts Project to Rebuild Homes Hit by War in Gaza Strip
item.description: The Qatari ambassador said materials for the $1 billion effort, which is to rebuild 1,000 homes, had arrived in Gaza from Israel.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI

item.title: Developing Nations Lose Their Luster
item.description: Once seen as a necessity in portfolios, investments in countries like Brazil and Russia are being reassessed because of messy politics and flagging economies.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: A currency exchange in Moscow. The Russian ruble has plunged 65 percent against the dollar, and remains volatile.

item.title: Date of Armenia’s Birth, Given in 5th Century, Gains Credence
item.description: Geneticists found Armenians to come from a mixing of populations that occurred from 3000 to 2000 B.C., coincident with the date given by a historian in the fifth century.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS WADE
